Elections the start of Egypt's democracy

The run off between the final two Presidential nominees, the former Prime Minister Ahmed Shafik and Mohammad Mursi, will take place with the decision having a very powerful effect on the future of Egypt (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: UN WOMEN ARAB STATES)

Leveson trundles on, but with few answers

Over the last few weeks the Leveson Inquiry has began to heat up, but despite big names facing interrogation there are questions over whether progress is actually being made (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: dcMS)

Coalition must take care with internet powers

As all people even minimally acquainted with the internet will have seen by now, the government plans to force internet and phone providers to store details of customer calls, emails and website visits in a major expansion of surveillance laws (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: PM's Office)

East-West relations cool on Syria

As Syria slowly descends into civil war, the diplomatic crisis between Russia, China and the west has become a heated throwback to the days of the Cold War (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Panarmenian_photo)

Can Russia escape from oppression?

In light of constitutional changes to silence dissent, Laura Hughes looks at what alternatives, if any, the Russian people can call upon to improve democracy. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: SOMIZ)

Global Focus

The <em> Nouse</em> Politics team summarises the biggest stories from around the world

Immigration figures will put universities at risk

Universities UK, which represents 134 vice chancellors, has warned including international students in immigration figures and new student visa restrictions, is putting British Universities and the British economy at risk (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: UK in Italy)

We must come to a peace in Afghanistan

The recent tragic deaths of two more British servicemen in Afghanistan highlighted the precarious situation the British continue to find themselves in Afghanistan (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Helmandblog)

Los Indignados protesters return to the streets of Spanish cities

This week saw the return of Los Indignados - the indignant ones - to the streets of Spain to restate their anger at the failure of Spanish democracy and protest against the injustices of their current economic strife (Thumbnail credit A member of the "Los Indignados" 15-M movement; graduate unemployment is at crippling highs in Spain Photo credit: CERONEGATIVO)

Minimum price for Scotland's alcohol

Last week the Scottish Government outlined its plans for minimum alcohol pricing. With an increased minimum cost per unit of 50p, the government aims to combat Scotland's binge drinking problem (Thumbnail credit The minimum price aims to improve Scotland's severe alcohol problems Photo credit: wordshore)

Finding time for gay marriage

The decision by Barack Obama to support same-sex marriage is a step in the right direction. Our Prime Minister should act similarly, argues Lauren Stevenson (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: FCO)

Queen's Speech: 'Coalition staying the course'

Isn't the State Opening of Parliament exciting? For one, it provides an opportunity for Londoners to line the streets, little plastic flags in full flow, to grab a peak at our Queen (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: UK Parliament)

Drones are an illegitimate way to wage war

President Obama's counter-terrorism adviser John Brennan claimed last week that drones are aiding America's 'war on terror' (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Island-Life)

Murdoch's position is under real threat

The Murdochs recently endured three days of questioning as part of the Leveson Inquiry (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: World Economic Forum)

Hollande poised to become President

Tomorrow the French public will go to the polls for the second round of their Presidential election (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Francois Hollande)

Greece: what went wrong?

Today, the Greek economy is sinking into a deep recession following great cuts in wages and pensions while economists and politicians debate (Thumbnail credit George Papandreou: can his successors achieve where he failed? (Photo credit: francediplomatie))

Vote for elected mayors England

While there appears to be a lack of public interest in the issue, if they are approved this could be a massive shake up for the country's political landscape (Thumbnail credit Labour backbencher Gisela Stuart is looking to stand in Birmingham (Photo credit: somerubbishusername))

Attack far right parties, but engage their supporters

The ubiquitous demonisation of individual members of extreme political parties has to stop, Ben Cross argues (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: lewishamdreamer)

NUS urges vice-chancellors to give tax savings to universities

The National Union of Students (NUS) has called on university heads to give the windfall they will receive from the reduction in the top rate of tax next year to students (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: NUS Scotland)

If this is what it is to be a Democrat, why bother?

Last week Kent Conrad, the Senate Budget Committee Chairman, seemingly introduced a budget. But the bill he marked up will not be brought to the floor of the Senate - doing so would be pointless in the partisan environment he now operates in (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Matt Artega)

Double dip dilemma for Osborne

With political uproar over the government's relationship with News International, the news that the country had slipped back into recession has culminated in an utterly disastrous start to the year (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: The CBI)

Brand calls for new drugs policy

Appearing in Parliament last Tuesday, renowned comedian and former heroin addict Russell Brand called for a pragmatic and compassionate approach towards dealing with drug use in the UK (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Eva Rinaldi)

Need we pay attention to protest votes?

The successes of George Galloway in England and Marie Le Pen in France are a potentially alarming development (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Neno)

Mayoral election not worth the name

The candidates' burning desire to solve the problems affecting Londoners or wealth of knowledge were apparent in the recent mayoral debates

Johnson promises to prevent "social cleansing"

Boris Johnson, seeking re-election in May, has expressed his dissatisfaction with the proposal to relocate thousands of low-income families outside of the capital from boroughs such as Newham and Westminster.

"Some People Are Gay. Get Over It!"

Rarely has a policy debate been so undeserving of that title. There is no valid argument against gay marriage, none at all. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: lewishamdreamer)

Despite Kyi's success, sanctions should remain

David Cameron should exercise greater caution before advocating, to the newly elected Aung San Suu Kyi, that the EU should suspend all but military sanctions in Burma (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Guillaume Paumier)

This election is not dealing with the real issues

Neither of the two main candidates for the French Presidency have answers to the challenging issues plaguing French politics. (Thumbnail credit Francois Hollande; the next French President? (Photo credit: Philippe Moreau Chevrolet))

Let's pick an outsider for the World Bank

The tradition that an American heads the World Bank undermines the credibility of the institution and freezes developing countries out of the process. It is time the Bank went in a different direction. (Thumbnail credit Nigerian Finance Minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala (Photo credit: World Economic Forum))

Budget 2012: Much ado about nothing

We've had five weeks of speculation, one hour of George Osborne and a fortnight of analysis based entirely on what party you support. Sensible economics seems like a long-lost friend. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: The Prime Minister's Office)
